I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts:
The city breathes, a beast of brick and steel, its veins choked with traffic. The places to live, they bleed into each other, a haphazard sprawl of concrete and glass. Stores, their windows dark and vacant, stand like sentinels against a tide of asphalt. A few, newer ones, bright and clean, still hold the scent of new paint and ambition.  

The air hums with a constant murmur, a low thrum of engines and the clatter of footsteps. The people move like shadows, faces etched with a thousand stories, their eyes flitting from side to side, ever watchful.  There are faces pale and drawn, faces etched with weariness, faces that hold a flicker of hope, and faces that have long since stopped looking.  

In this concrete jungle, there are pockets of life, small islands of humanity clinging to the fringes. The old haunts, the familiar faces, the echoes of laughter and sorrow.  A park, a haven of green amidst the grey, where children chase pigeons and mothers whisper secrets.  A small gathering of storefronts, each a testament to the dreams of a few, a tapestry of cultures woven into the fabric of the city.

But beneath the surface, a darkness lingers. A sense of isolation, a gnawing emptiness. The city swallows you whole, its vastness both a blessing and a curse. It offers opportunity, but it demands a price. A price paid in lost dreams, broken hearts, and the slow erosion of the soul. 

And yet, there is a beauty here, too. A raw, untamed beauty, a resilience that blooms in the cracks of the pavement. A flicker of light in the darkness, a whisper of hope in the wind. The city is a living thing, a constant state of flux, a tapestry woven from the threads of human experience.

The houses huddled close, a row of weary old bones beneath a sky the color of ash. Most were single, standing solitary in their yards, but some, twinned together like drunken lovers, bore the mark of a simpler time. A time when the dream of a patch of green and a two-car garage still held sway, a time before the dream began to fade, to shrink back from the world like a wounded animal. 

My house, it sits there, like the rest, a faded photograph of what was. A small yard, a driveway swallowed by weeds, the paint chipped and peeling like sunburned skin. The air hangs heavy with the memory of lawnmowers and barbecues, of children's laughter echoing in the twilight. But the laughter has grown thin now, the yards are choked with grass, and the cars sit idle, their chrome dulled by time and neglect. 

The public school, a stone sentinel against the encroaching twilight, stands tall. Its classrooms still echo with the ghosts of past generations, its halls still whisper of dreams and aspirations. The basketball courts, though, they are alive. The thud of the ball, the scrape of sneakers on asphalt, they are the only sound that truly breaks the silence.

The churches stand empty, their doors locked against the wind. But the spirit of faith lingers, a faint echo in the hearts of those who remain.  The supermarket, a concrete monolith named "Super A," is a testament to the changing times. Owned by an Arab family, they stand apart from the sea of familiar faces. The majority of the neighborhood, they are Black, their history intertwined with the very fabric of this place.

There's a movie theater, a relic from a bygone era. It shows old films, forgotten stories flickering across a faded screen. The young ones, they scoff at it, their eyes glued to the bright lights and empty promises of the digital world. But the elders, they gather in its dim recesses, seeking solace in the familiarity of a time gone by.

The expressway, it cuts through the town next door, a scar of concrete and steel. A petition for an exit, it was proposed, but the elders, they resisted. They claimed it would bring decay, that it would taint the purity of their world. So the expressway remains a distant rumble, a reminder of the forces that shape their lives.

Now, they are building a new high school, a symbol of hope for the future. The town, it debates its mascot, trying to find a symbol that reflects its spirit. A cyborg, they say, with a country accent and a log cabin. A strange combination, perhaps, but it speaks to the duality of their existence, caught between the past and the uncertain future.

The place could be passed over easy. Just another strip mall backwater, a collection of worn-out storefronts and shuttered signs.  But back behind the carcass of the Whole Foods, past the vacant hotels that saw a flicker of life only in summer, a different world unfolds. A string of apartment blocks, huddled together like cast-off dolls, their bones laid bare. The first one, stained with whispers of bad dealings, is best left untouched. But the ones beside it, those are where the secrets gather.  Across the street, a community college campus sits like a sentinel, its low brick walls holding a sleepwalker's pace. Students shuffle in, eyes heavy, clutching coffee cups, while impatient drivers curse their slow procession. The street bleeds into another, lined with a park where children spin and tumble, oblivious to the world. A rehabilitation center, its porch furniture a faded promise of hope, stands stiffly across the way. The air hangs thick and sweet, a lazy ceiling fan churning it back and forth like a forgotten dream.

Beside the park, a strip mall hums. A sushi place, perpetually half-empty, offers cheap meals, while a swimming store sits beside it, next to a nail salon where women gossip and laugh over chipped polish.  Down the street, a frozen yogurt parlor, a monument to teenage rebellion, is besieged by kids, their cups sticky with artificial sweetness. They skateboard, vape, and pretend the world can wait.  This is a place where time moves slow. A forgotten corner of Americana, where the past hangs heavy in the air, a whisper of what was, and what could have been.

The cornfields stretched on, a sea of green under the pale sun. "Where is everything?" she asked, her voice thin against the vastness.  She'd come from a place where the edges of things were sharp, defined.  This, this was different. This was emptiness made solid.  She didn't understand.

"This is it," I said, knowing the shock would come. This was the land that shaped me, the quiet hum of its heart beating against my own. I told her of growing up here, of the seasons turning, the wind whispering through the stalks.

The road dipped and climbed, swallowing the horizon in its dust. We passed a quarry, its waters black and still as ink, reflecting the sky like a broken mirror. Past that, the houses huddled, brick and stucco, each one a small island in a sea of green.  They were proud of their land, these people, taking care of it like a sacred thing. The driveways gleamed, polished by the sun, filled with cars that seemed to hum with a silent power.

My Korean neighbor, a man whose face was a map of laughter lines and time, was tending his lawn.  He sang as he worked, a thin, cheerful sound carried on the wind. He'd been a doctor once, they said, and the stories of his life were etched in the way he moved, the way he looked at the world.

The house came into view, grey stucco against the green. Geese honked in the side yard, chased by our terrier. Beyond the back door, a small stream gurgled, feeding into the quarry.  Bullfrogs croaked, and the distant moo of a cow drifted on the air.

Across the bridge, a small haven. Trees, wild and untamed, stood sentinel. Herbs and wildflowers bloomed in the dappled sunlight. This was where I'd spent my childhood, building forts, chasing shadows, dreaming dreams that tasted of dirt and sun.

Winter came then, a harsh embrace. Trees stood bare, their branches clawing at the sky. The ground turned hard and white, a silent expanse under a pale sun. Snow fell, transforming the world into a wonderland of white and grey. Snow angels, snowmen, and the echoes of laughter.

There were fights, too, skirmishes waged with snowballs, fought under the watchful gaze of the bare trees.  We built our forts, icy castles against the wind, hiding within, safe in our own world.

The wind off the Columbia bites with a chill that seeps into the bones. It whispers through the pines, a low moan that carries the scent of rain and decay. Portland. They call it weird. A slogan scrawled on some crumbling brick, a testament to a time when the city still breathed a little easier. Maybe it's true. Maybe the ghosts of the past cling to these streets, to the faded murals and the boarded-up storefronts.  There's a kind of magic here, a ragged beauty that blooms in the cracks of the asphalt. A free box on the sidewalk, overflowing with yesterday's treasures: a chipped china teacup, a dog-eared book of poetry, a faded photograph of a young girl with eyes that seem to follow you. It's a city of contradictions, a symphony of the familiar and the strange. The aroma of freshly brewed coffee mingles with the tang of saltwater and the earthy scent of damp wood. A symphony of clanging trams and the rumble of distant logging trucks.

You see it in the faces of the people, etched with the weariness of a city that never sleeps, yet holds onto a flicker of hope. They wear their eccentricities like badges of honor, their tattoos and piercings a testament to a life lived on their own terms. A kaleidoscope of humanity, from the tattooed barista serving up artisanal lattes to the weathered man reciting poetry on a street corner.

But beneath the surface, a darkness lingers. The rain, a constant companion, washes over the city, blurring the lines between reality and dreams. The homeless man huddled in a doorway, his eyes vacant and haunted. The drug addict, his body ravaged by addiction, clutching a syringe like a lifeline. These are the shadows that haunt the city's soul, a reminder that even in the midst of weirdness, there is pain.

Portland is a city of layers, a tapestry woven from threads of beauty and decay, hope and despair. A place where the ordinary and the extraordinary collide.  A place where you can be yourself, or whoever you want to be, and find a semblance of belonging.

The mountains. They are always there. Northward, watching the sun bleed across the sky each day, each night. No matter how I turn from them, how I bury myself in the days, they are there. Solid, unyielding. Unfazed. 

And when the world presses down, when the mind claws at itself, they call to me. I turn then, and their silence gives me strength. A strength to walk another day.

I came here for school, a boy then. The mountains north of campus were the first thing that took hold.  The school itself, with its brick and stone and ivy, has its own beauty. Its ponds and gardens, their own secrets. But the mountains, they hold the true heart.

The town itself unfolds around them. A blur of cafes where thoughts were brewed and burnt, of brick buildings whispering stories of a forgotten time. A downtown that hums with life, a heartbeat quickening, then fading as you walk past the library. 

This town, it holds two faces. And yet, it is this duality that makes it sing. A place to build memories, cherish them. Laughter echoing in the park, the rust of swings a lullaby. The rush of the downtown, the bright lights of the cinema, a stolen kiss in the shadows. And then, the quiet ponds, where tears fall like rain, and the reflection of the sky mirrors the turmoil within.

Those ponds, they hold the weight of the world. I’ve sat there, watched the turtles glide, the ducks quack, the insects dance, and wondered at my own place in this vast, unknowable thing called life. Walking past the pond, past the houses that seem to sigh with age, I found myself drawn north. 

The sun, a blaze of gold, touched the tops of the palm trees, painting the sky in fire. And there they were, the mountains, their peaks piercing the haze.  Silent, strong, they spoke a language older than words. A language of perseverance. A language I understood.

The sun bled a pale light across the asphalt, a thin haze hanging low over Bensonhurst. You'd find it easy enough, the neighborhood.  Trains run thick as fleas on a dog in this city, and Bensonhurst, it clings to the tracks like a barnacle. Still feels like the city, but with a different kind of hunger. 

Walk down any street and you'll see the signs. The shops, they whisper of rice and spice, of languages older than the subway lines that thread beneath the ground.  Asian faces stare out from storefronts, supermarkets stacked high with goods from distant shores. 

They say good food comes from the heart, and these folks, they pour their hearts out in every bowl of noodles, every steamed dumpling. Cheap, too, and plentiful.  And the laundry, oh, the laundry.  It’s a ritual, the way they fold and press, the steam rising like prayers. 

But don’t mistake this for a colony, a place cut off from the rest. This is New York, after all.  Black and white faces mingle, Spanish and Korean voices rise in the air.  A tapestry woven with threads of every tongue and every story.

There's a park, a patch of green swallowed by the concrete jungle.  Basketball hoops stand silent, waiting for the squeak of sneakers.  Children chase laughter on the swings, their cries lost in the rumble of traffic.  A field of dreams, maybe, or just a place to dream of something else.

The houses are close together, two families sharing a single brick facade.  A symphony of noise rises from their doors – slamming, shouting, the whine of a radio.  At night, the streets hold their breath, the silence thick and pregnant.  Then comes the rumble, the growl of car engines, the bass thump of music, a warning to stay alert.  Be cautious.  This city, it has a way of swallowing you whole if you let it.

The hill slopes down, a wound in the earth, and my house sits perched at its crown. A crown of nothing, really. No sidewalks here, just the black ribbon of the road snaking through the gloom. A road chewed up and spitting gravel, a hazard for tires and a haven for the wind. Overhead, the wires sag, a patchwork of gray and rust, a testament to the storms that come in thick and heavy, stripping branches from the trees and leaving the whole place shivering in the dark.  

They hate the trees, the people here.  Each one a block to the view, a barrier to the ocean. So they build their houses high, like wounded birds, glass eyes staring out at the water. They want that view, that sliver of sky and sea, even if it's most often veiled in a shroud of gray. 

The sun, when it breaks through, sets the water ablaze, a molten heart beating in the belly of the bay. But the clouds, they come and go like restless spirits, smothering the light, leaving a world washed in a perpetual dampness. Moss, a green velvet, clings to everything, to roof and car, to the rusted bars of the old gate.  I once forgot my car, parked out front, for a month. Found it draped in a coat of emerald, a creeping tomb. Three hours it took to scrape the life from it. 

Children are scarce here, ghosts flitting through the empty streets.  Older folks, mostly, their houses filled with the ghosts of laughter that used to echo through the halls. Dogs, they are the constant companions, shadows padding on the worn pavement, their barks the only sound that breaks the silence.  Leave a door ajar, and you might find a furry intruder curled up on your sofa, a pair of eyes gleaming in the dim light.

Rabbits, they run wild, their burrows hidden in the lawns, their noses twitching, their teeth gnawing.  The gardeners curse them, the cats adore them. A tense dance, predator and prey, played out in the twilight.  Sparrows flit amongst the trees, hummingbirds dart like jewels, and occasionally a hawk, a silent shadow against the gray sky, circles overhead, chased away by the raucous croaking of the crows. 

There are no shops in this hollow, just a few restaurants huddled by the water's edge, their windows smelling of salt and fish.  The beach, it's not much, just a sliver of sand swallowed by the tide. But the rocks, they are a constant temptation, heavy and smooth, waiting to be hurled into the bay, sending up a spray of silver in the air.  The water, it stretches out, a wide mirror reflecting the clouds, the sky, the ever-present gray. The other shore, it's a whisper away, a hazy line against the horizon.

The street ran like a scar through the heart of the town, a ribbon of asphalt connecting the two black veins of highway.  Traffic hummed along it, a constant murmur against the quiet. It was a place where folks were known, faces familiar beneath the peeling paint of houses, the rusted hulls of cars that sat half-forgotten in driveways.  There were kids, of course, their laughter echoing like brittle leaves against the stillness. They rode bikes, kicked dust devils in the heat, chased each other through the dying light.  Small lives unfolding in a landscape of routine, a tapestry woven from yard work, dinners, and the hushed conversations of neighbors on porches.  Our corner house, nestled at the intersection, held a kind of vigil over it all. We saw them all come and go, the routines, the rhythms.  Sometimes, a stranger would pass, a car with a foreign license plate, its dust a new mark on the landscape. It would linger in the mind, a ripple in the still pond of the familiar.

We were four souls bound within those walls, my wife, our daughters, and I. We worked our days within the house, the hum of the computers a counterpoint to the rustle of leaves outside.   There were days when the smell of grilling meat, a smoky benediction, would drift through the air, mingling with the scent of cut grass, the ever-present perfume of dying things turning to earth. The winter was a brittle thing, a fleeting visitor that barely touched the land before retreating back into the cold.  It was the fall that truly held sway, the leaves turning, a slow, deliberate surrender to the coming darkness. We'd burn them, piles of crimson and gold, their smoke a silent farewell. 

The garage, a sanctuary at the back of the house, held the ghosts of projects past and the promise of future ones.  The garage door, a portal, swung open, and the world beyond seemed more immediate, more alive.  Holidays brought a brief flurry of activity, a burst of color and sound, the quickening pulse of life. Then, the silence would return, the rhythm of the street resuming its slow, relentless march. It was a place of small moments, of quiet lives, a canvas painted in shades of gray and green, of rust and dust. It was home, a kind of sanctuary in the heart of the ordinary.

The flatlands stretched out, brown and endless. Dirt. Always dirt. They say out here, you learn to appreciate the green, the way a parched man craves water. Lawns, they’re a testament to a different kind of hunger, a thirst for something more than survival. When I first came here, back in the 90s, houses were scattered like tumbleweeds, each one a tiny island in the sea of dust. Now, the islands are closing in, the desert choked by progress. They call it growth, but it feels more like decay, a slow suffocation. 

The folks here, they’re mostly salt-of-the-earth types. Friendly, for the most part. The kind who greet you with a nod and a “howdy.” But like any place with bones, there are shadows here too. 

The stores, they’re the same ones you’d find anywhere else – chains swallowing up the landscape. Food for Less, Smart & Final. You want Whole Foods, you gotta drive.  Construction, that’s the lifeblood of this place. The land’s still hungry, still yearning to be built upon.  It scares me, that hunger. I came here to escape the city, not to see it creep in. 

I work with my hands, drywall and T-bar. Honest labor. It’s a way to exist, to carve out a space for myself in this relentless landscape. But the desert, it doesn’t forget. It remembers the things you try to hide. 

The animals, they’re a different story. Lizards skittering across the sunbaked earth, beetles with iridescent wings. My kids, they’re fascinated by them.  Right now, they’re out back, nets in hand, trying to catch a glimpse of something wild.

There are things to see here, if you know where to look. The mountains, they stand like silent giants against the sky. And the night, oh, the night. A black velvet canvas splashed with stars. You can almost feel the universe breathing here, a vast and ancient presence.

We’ve made a life here, out on the edge of things. It’s not for everyone, but it’s home.

The college, it's my neighborhood. Always has felt that way. Not like the houses and yards of others, but close enough. My community, the folks in the dorms. The campus itself, that's the rest of it.  Stores, a scattering of them, a park or two, all within reach. 

The houses here, they ain't like most. Apartments, crammed tight, four or five floors, twenty souls maybe, all crammed in. Then there are the houses, scattered 'round, for the older folks, the ones who've made their mark. Few and far between, though. Mostly it's the dorms, rows of 'em, brick and concrete, two to a room, hundreds of youngsters underneath a single roof.

Folks here, they come from everywhere. A tapestry, woven from every thread. The older ones, they tend to the houses, making their home among the roots of the institution. The young ones, they flock to the dorms, their bones still soft, their minds eager.

You can't talk about a neighborhood without its heart, and that's the people.  They're the lifeblood, the pulse of this place.  Always moving, always changing, always coming together in the shadow of the brick towers. 

The stores, well, they're a necessity. Food, clothes, the things you need to survive.  A taste of home in a strange land. And the park, it's a haven. A place to breathe, to think, to be.  A patch of green in a sea of concrete.

The road had wound ten years deep into this place. Ten years since the move from Riverdale, a town swallowed by the dust of memory. Tears had spilled that day, a weeping for what was left behind. But the parents, they knew better. A better life, a better school, a house that didn't sigh with the ghosts of hard times.  Stockbridge. A place where the air itself tasted different, cleaner somehow. 

Friends were made, enemies too, in the shifting currents of adolescence. Neighbors remained strangers, faces glimpsed in passing. Except for Mr. Glen, his wife Veda, and their children. They were a warmth in the cold grid of this new life. Almost family.  I remember the wedding, a second chance at promise under the summer sun. Veda, shedding the old, throwing a white strap into the air, a silent letting go. I caught it, a small blessing.  The music pulsed, bodies swayed, and Marsharii, one of their daughters, held my gaze across the dance floor. A fleeting connection, a brush of possibility. Where she is now, I don't know. Maybe a queen in her own right.

The neighborhood, a labyrinth of streets, a map etched in memory. Now with the aid of a device that knows every twist and turn, I can explore its secrets at my own pace. There are places I haven't seen, paths untrodden. Places where Kason and Curtis, companions in the digital realms, have walked before. Video games, laughter, the fleeting joy of youth.

Sometimes, I seek solace in the park. The whispering trees, the rustling leaves, a balm for the soul. Sticks from the hardware store become swords, balancing practice under the watchful eyes of the ancient oaks.  A basketball court, a tennis court, silent echoes of games long played.  My father, a stern but loving hand guiding my swings, Mr. Graves, a master of the backhand, those lessons etched in muscle memory.  

Ten years. A tapestry woven with moments, threads of joy, sorrow, and the quiet hum of existence.  The best, I know, is yet to come.

The neighborhood pressed close. Brick and mortar, stacked high and weary, a few skeletal trees reaching for the sky between them.  It wasn't much to look at, not like those shiny new towers down the way, built too fast, hollow inside.  They reeked of money and dust. This place, it had the smell of old cigarettes and rain, of cheap grease and cheap laughter spilling out from the bars that clung to life like barnacles. 

My place, it was a small hold in the city's belly, a place where faces were fleeting, where kids ran barefoot and voices echoed in the stairwells.  There were ghosts in the walls, whispers of lives lived and lost. I knew them not, these ghosts, but they were the silence between the laughter, the echo in the empty hallways.

The college, it was a stone's throw away, a beacon of hope in the grey. But the streets, they twisted and turned, choked by weeds and cracked concrete.  The air was thick with the scent of exhaust and burnt sugar, the taste of iron in the rain.  

Sometimes, the night was a canvas, painted black with the blues of distant sirens.  Sometimes, it was a shroud, heavy and suffocating. But always, there was a pulse, a thrumming beneath the surface, the city's heartbeat, a rhythm that echoed in my bones. 

This was my home, a ragged tapestry woven from shadows and light, where the past clung to the present like a shroud. This was my place.

The houses huddled together like teeth in a rusted jaw. Duplexes, each painted the same pale yellow, their porches like bleached bones beneath the green tin roofs. Not quite a town, not quite a village. A cul-de-sac of whispers and shared glances. Children, their laughter thin and sharp as broken glass, chased each other through the heat, their games a blur of color against the relentless blue. 

The air hung heavy, thick with the scent of pine and something else, something ancient and unsettling. A low, constant hum throbbed beneath the surface, the hum of a world on the edge of something vast and unknowable. This was the only place she knew, this pocket of normalcy stitched into the fabric of a world gone mad.

The storm came without warning, a sudden rush of wind and a sky choked with black. A scream ripped through the air, the wail of the sirens slicing through the quiet. The dog whined, pressing against her legs, his eyes wide and frantic. She scooped him up, the weight of him a comfort against the growing fear. Her purse, her dog, a pillow, and the cold porcelain of the bathtub became her sanctuary. The hail hammered against the roof, a furious drumming that mirrored the frantic beat of her own heart.

The world outside was swallowed by darkness, the air thick with the smell of ozone and fear. The storm passed, leaving behind a silence so profound it felt like a physical presence. She stepped outside, blinking against the light, and saw the world reborn. The air shimmered with heat, the pavement steamed beneath her feet. A double rainbow arced across the sky, a fragile promise of beauty in a world teetering on the edge of chaos. 

The neighborhood, bruised but unbroken, began to stir. Children, their faces smeared with dirt and tears, emerged from their shelters. The air was filled with the murmur of voices, the clinking of teacups, the laughter of children.  A sense of normalcy, fragile and precious, returned.

She walked, her feet sinking into the soft earth, the scent of rain and pine filling her lungs. The rooster crowed, a defiant burst of sound in the stillness. The donkey brayed in the distance, a lonely echo in the vastness of the world. This was home.  This was where she belonged.

The dust settled slow on the houses, two stories tall, all neat and matched like soldiers in a row. I came here the year the cicadas screamed their last. Eighth grade, they called it. A stranger in a strange land. It took time, a long time, but I found my way. Two houses down, a boy with eyes like flint, and another a block over, his laughter like the tang of honeysuckle on a summer night. They're gone now, scattered by the wind like fallen leaves, but the memory of them lingers, a ghost of a laugh in the stillness.

The folks here, they're the same. Same smiles, same routines. The world outside, it churns and changes, but here, time moves slower, the dust settles deeper. The kids, they still play in the street, their shouts echoing in the empty air. Sundays, the air thick with the smell of charcoal and burgers. Evenings, the quiet comes down like a shroud, broken only by the rustle of leaves and the ticking of unseen clocks.

There's a park, a green patch in the midst of all this gray. A place where memories bloom, stark and sharp. Basketball hoops, their rust stained red, stand sentinel. I played there once, young and reckless, a football ripped from my grasp, a nosebleed, the sting of pain. But there's laughter too, echoes of childhood, the squeal of swings, the shrieks of pure joy. Now, it's different. My cousin's kids, their eyes wide with wonder, their small hands clutching at the swings. They chase the ghosts of laughter, oblivious to the shadows that creep in the corners.

Food, it's everywhere. A tapestry of smells, a symphony of flavors. Chinese, Indian, Mexican, Italian. A world condensed into a mile radius. Yet, it's the same old story. The drive-throughs hum, the delivery apps drone, a constant hunger that can never be truly satisfied.

Walgreens, CVS, Jewel-Osco. The names are familiar, the shelves stocked with the things we need, the things we crave. An Indian store, tucked away, a haven of spices and scents, a reminder of a world beyond.

This place, it's a refuge, a haven in a storm. Reading the stories, seeing the headlines, it makes you appreciate the quiet, the normalcy. Here, there's a sense of belonging, a thread of kinship woven through the dust and the sunshine. It's not perfect, but it's home.

The town of Johnston clung to the flatlands of South Carolina, a place unmarked on any map save the one held in the heart of its people. Peach trees, their limbs heavy with the fruit, stretched out like skeletal fingers across the landscape, casting long shadows in the heat. Cattle grazed in the fields, their low moans a constant hum in the air. Houses, mostly two-story affairs, huddled together like wary animals, their metal roofs glinting in the harsh sun. They stood apart from the road, their yards swallowed by fields of ripening peaches or grazed by restless hooves. 

A single stoplight, a blinking red eye in the midday sun, marked the center of town. Around it clustered the meager offerings of commerce. Hong Kong, the lone Chinese restaurant, its windows dusty and its air thick with the scent of ginger and garlic, stood beside Fiesta Mexican, a cheerful yellow facade against the muted browns and greens. Gary’s, with its plastic red booths and greasy burgers, completed the trio of fast food options. A ghost of a pizzeria lingered, its sign faded and its windows dark. 

Inside Maxwell and Halford Drug, the air hung heavy with the scent of cough syrup and peppermint. Behind the counter, the old pharmacist, his face creased with a thousand stories, would dispense Cherry Coke, a local legend, its sweet fizz a balm for weary souls. The IGA, a cramped space overflowing with shelves stacked high with canned goods and dusty boxes of cereal, stood as the town's lone grocery store. Its aisles, however, echoed with the whispers of discontent, for many preferred the bounty and variety of Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville. Dollar General, a beacon of fluorescent light and discounted goods, pulsed with the constant hum of commerce.

Possibilities Furniture & More, its sign peeling in the heat, held the promise of comfort and a thousand different dreams. The owner, a woman with a kind smile and calloused hands, knew the town’s secrets, each piece of furniture a silent witness to its joys and sorrows. Attached, Clark’s Cuts and Kennels, a haven for furry companions, offered a refuge from the heat and the dust.

The doctor's office, a small brick building with peeling paint, stood on the edge of town, its waiting room filled with the whispered anxieties of its patients. The veterinary clinic, a haven for four-legged souls, offered solace and healing to the town’s animals. Johnston Elementary School, its walls painted a faded yellow, held the promise of a future, but its students knew that beyond fifth grade, their paths would lead them away.

Johnston was a place where time moved slowly, where the clock ticked to the rhythm of the seasons and the whispers of the wind through the peach trees. There were no grand spectacles here, no flashing lights or bustling crowds. Just the quiet hum of life, the slow unfolding of days, and the enduring spirit of a town that clung to its roots.

The first time the name of this place had come to him, he was listening to some rustle of voices on the radio, folks talking about disappearances.  Strange, he'd thought. Apartments here, they were going for a king's ransom.  A thousand dollars a month and more. Never heard a whisper of this story, nor had any of the others he knew. Maybe that's the way of it, life in this place. A struggle, a constant gnaw. He knew some of the young ones, tears in their eyes at night.  Things were tight, yes, but they'd learned to make do. To find a kind of beauty in the dust-laced trinkets of the pawn shops, the faded clothes in the thrift bins. The smell of it, that's what you got used to. The smell of a life lived cheaply. Like mothballs and forgotten dreams. Here, there were three of them, these places of cast-offs. Three thrift stores within spitting distance.  Walk down from the far side, and you could hit two of the charity kind, a library with stacks that smelled of time, a place for old books, and a curio shop crammed with whispers from a forgotten past. Downtown, that was a different beast. Cars and people, a tide that never seemed to recede. But inside the stores, it was quiet. The din of the city couldn't touch them. A good place to lose yourself. 

Every year, more and more of those tide-like things came. Cars, people, all flowing into the heart of it. A young city, they called it. Growing, stretching, straining. Like a child on the cusp of manhood. Headquartering one of those online empires, the one that delivered everything to your door.  It reminded him of someplace he'd once known, a name that slipped his mind. Everything and everyone rushing toward something, an invisible goal.  No one asked much of you here. You could be alone, quiet, lost in your own thoughts. It was different from down south, where everyone knew everyone else's business. Here, you kept your own counsel, your own secrets.  Let the city wash over you, a wave that broke and retreated. 

They had a pianist next door, a constant murmur of music. And upstairs, two souls who felt the need to share their voices with the world. Not always beautiful, but always present.  The city was a chorus, a symphony of life, and you were a single note, blending in, standing out, disappearing. It wasn't a bad place to be.


They had a kind of community here. A loose string of souls who came together for birthdays and funerals, for shared meals and quiet conversations. They looked out for each other, helped when they could. For that, he was grateful.  He lived in a place of concrete and steel, a monument to human ambition, but these people, these neighbors, they made it feel human again.  They made him feel like maybe, just maybe, he hadn't completely screwed it all up.

The houses here, they huddle close, all brick and glass, like ants under a magnifying glass.  They wear the same bland faces, each one a mirror of the next.  The lawn, a patch of green scraped bare and regimented, is the same for every yard. A few stones, a stunted tree, a driveway like a scar across the earth. Two-car garages, all lined up in a row, like teeth in a gaping maw.

The roads are smooth, black ribbons, freshly poured, a testament to the watchful eye of the association.  No cracks, no potholes, just the endless stretch of asphalt reflecting the pale sky.  The houses themselves, mostly single-story, stand hushed and watchful. A few rise higher, two stories, but even they share the same stoic silence.

Forget the mailboxes by the curb, the kind you see in pictures. Here, they've been corralled together, a metal hutch at the end of the road.  A key, a code, a uniformity that binds them all.

Out here, on the edge of town, the asphalt gives way to fields. The city's breath hangs heavy on the air, but it's a breath that fades quickly, swallowed by the vastness of the land. There are pools, shimmering and clean, guarded by fences and gates. Trails wind through the scrub, paths to nowhere, just a way to walk and pretend you're somewhere else.

Most days, the air is filled with the murmur of silence. Old folks, their days spent in the comfortable routines of a life well-lived. Young couples, eyes fixed on the future, a future that whispers promises of quiet and stability.  They come and go, these people, but they all walk the same path.

The city itself is a beast of a different kind. Big, yes, but with the heart of a small town.  One mall, a place where you can find anything you need, or anything you think you need.  High-end groceries, places where the food is so perfect it seems almost unnatural.  Bargain stores, piled high with goods, a testament to the insatiable hunger for something more.

And me? I live here, in the quiet corners, watching the world go by.  The houses, the roads, the people, they all blur together, a tapestry of sameness.  But sometimes, in the stillness of the night, I can feel the edges of it all, the hum of something vast and unknown, waiting just beyond the reach of the light.

The town sits huddled in the shadow of the city, a place forgotten by the sun. Eastward, where the houses huddle together like ghosts, mine stands among them. Hard-pressed folk, mostly, renting, scraping by. Good people, though. They nod and wave. 

But the city's sickness seeps down here.  You hear the sirens, the distant cries, a fever that chills the soul. There's been a whisper of violence. Shootings, a man left to rot in the doorway of a store. Our own neighbors, kind souls, lost a son to a bullet in the street. It ain't constant, like a plague in the city, but it lingers like smoke in a room.  

This whole land is poisoned. They call it the opioid epidemic. A slow death, swallowing folks whole. There's places here to fight it, clinics, folks learning to pull the dying back from the edge. But the fight is long and hard, a losing battle for some.

My boy, God bless him, he goes to a decent school. Teachers, principal - they care. He's got needs, different ways, but they make him feel safe. They feed him, too. Breakfast and lunch for all, no matter how thin the wallet. No one's looked down upon here for being poor.

The town's been trying to mend itself. New pavement, trees planted, parks scrubbed clean. But the work's mostly on the other side, where the shops are, where the rich folks live. Our side, it's left behind, forgotten. 

Still, it's home. We've been here sixteen years. The house ain't much, but it's ours. The folks are decent, the school's alright, and there's enough to get by. This is where we belong.

The Hilltop pressed close, a fist of brick and stone reaching for the sky.  Buildings leaned into each other, their stories etched in the grain of the weathered facades.  Across the street, the old Theater stood sentinel, its marquee dark, a silent maw. On nights thick with summer heat, the arcade bar down the street pulsed with a neon heartbeat, drawing in a motley crew seeking refuge from the city's grime. A line snaked out its door, a testament to the desperate yearning for connection, for a brief respite from the relentless churn. 

The park, a concrete island in the heart of the fray, offered little solace. In winter, it became a canvas for the transient, their tents huddled against the biting wind, a fragile constellation against the backdrop of the city's indifference. The rain, relentless and unforgiving, turned the pavement to slick black mirrors, reflecting the bleakness of the sky. But here, in their proximity, they shared a fragile warmth, a bond forged in the crucible of hardship.  

The city's heart was a tangle of contradictions. It boasted of beauty, of its towering monuments and architectural whimsy, but the true heart beat in the grit, in the resilience of the people. Hilltop, once the city's scar, bore the weight of its past like a shroud.  Whispers of its violent history, of the DEA's iron grip, lingered in the air, a constant reminder of its troubled soul.  

Yet, something had shifted. The people, scarred but unbroken, had chosen to fight back.  They scrubbed the streets, tended their gardens, held onto their dreams with a fierce determination. Their allegiance wasn't to color or creed, but to the shared experience of survival. The warnings about walking alone at night, those were relics of a bygone era, echoes of fear clinging to the fringes of a changing reality. 

I, a transplant, had found solace in this crucible of humanity. Here, amidst the remnants of a troubled past, I felt a kinship, a recognition in the shared gaze of strangers.  There was kindness in the outstretched hand, a shared understanding in the silence of a rainy night. Hilltop wasn't a place; it was a state of being, a testament to the enduring spirit of those who refused to be broken.  It was home.

The town sits hunched between the two lakes, Michigan and Charlevoix, their waters mirroring the gray sky. No concrete giants here, no glowing screens promising escape. Just the slow rustle of wind through pine needles, the distant rumble of a pickup truck on the gravel road. Houses cluster like a huddle against the chill, each one a story etched in wood and paint. Some stand weathered and proud, their bones exposed, others freshly patched and painted, straining for a youth that has long passed.

Basements, deep and cool, yawn open beneath the earth, their shadows stretching across the lawns. Aluminum siding glistens in the weak sun, a patchwork of colors against the backdrop of evergreens. Yards stretch out, tamed and purposeful. Trampolines bound with youthful energy, swingsets creak a lullaby. Here and there, a garden blooms defiant, a splash of color against the muted palette.

The air hums with the lifeblood of families, the steady rhythm of work and play. Children chase each other through the streets, their laughter echoing off the clapboard walls. Dogs bark greetings, their tails wagging a welcome. Neighbors nod, a silent understanding passing between them. A grill smokes on a porch, the scent of charcoal and hope drifting on the breeze.

It's not a neighborhood that shouts its beauty, but whispers it. The kind of place where doors remain unlocked, where a handshake seals a deal, where trust is earned not given. The sheriff's office stands sentinel, a reassuring presence against the quiet backdrop. The health department, the recycling center, all nestled close, woven into the fabric of the town.

The crack of a baseball bat, the whir of a plane taking off, the laughter of children playing, these are the sounds that shape the day. A walk to the ice cream parlor, a bike ride to the park, a quiet evening on the porch watching the fireflies dance in the twilight.

Here, at the edge of the world, life unfolds at its own pace. A place to put down roots, to build a life, to find solace in the simple things. A place to belong.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all.
